titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller University records, Director, Herbert Spencer Gasser, Correspondence, Series 2
A Guide to the Rockefeller University records, Director, Herbert Spencer Gasser, Correspondence, Series 2 FA143
titlestmt.author: Ruth Sternfeld

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-03-07 00:11:28 -0500.

did.unittitle: Rockefeller University records, Director, Herbert Spencer Gasser, Correspondence, Series 2

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Herbert Spencer Gasser was Director of The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research 1935-1953. During his tenure he continued many of the administrative routines which had been established during the directorship of Simon Flexner. Thus, much administrative correspondence, in particular, matters dealing with personnel and administration of the physical plant are to be found in the papers of the Business Manager, Edric B. Smith, who served also, as Secretary of the Board of Trustees.
See FA137 Rockefeller University records, Business Manager, Subject Files, Series 3. See FA809 Rockefeller University records, Business Manager, Series 4.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Herbert Spencer Gasser, 1888-1963, physiologist, was Director of The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, 1935-1953. His early work at the University of Wisconsin and at Washington University was done on circulation and respiration, including the mechanism through which the heart is accelerated in exercise and the rate of decreased oxidation in the respiratory center. Later at Washington University and at Cornell University Medical College his major interest was in the physiology of nerve, developing electrophysiological techniques through the development of vacuum tube amplification and the cathode ray oscillograph. In collaboration with Joseph Erlanger, also of Washington University, he developed an exhaustive determination of the constants of nerve fibers and the classification of nerve fibers in accordance with their properties. The two men shared the Nobel Prize in Medicine and Physiology in 1944 for this work.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Herbert Spencer Gasser collection was deposited with the Rockefeller University Archives by The University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists entirely of correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Including incoming and outgoing letters. Number in parenthesis indicates number of items. A concise description is included where correspondence is voluminous or deals with a subject of particular interest or covers a number of years.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically including incoming and outgoing letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Of the correspondence in the Gasser papers, no clear distinction between administrative, professional and personal matters is apparent. They are in one alphabetical arrangement. A small amount of correspondence which is clearly personal, such as letters of appointment, receipt of honorary degrees and congratulatory letters on appointment as Director of the Institute and other honors (particularly Nobel Prize matters) were maintained in separate files and have been inventoried and listed with biographical and laboratory papers in the Biographical Material, Series 6 (FA814).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence between friends who are also professional colleagues which includes plans for vacation trips as well as arrangements for lectureships or honors. Includes arrangements for Gasser/Erlanger Johnson Foundation lectures in 1936. Includes 1939 Bronk biographical sketch and bibliography (5 holographs) and 1950 photo at Welch Centennial dinner.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This correspondence is divided by subject into three folders and each is arranged in chronological order.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Gasser served on a Standing Committee of the Federation on International Congresses with Drs. Walter B. Cannon and Donald Van Slyke with responsibility to pass on Federation membership of papers submitted by Local Committees for presentation at the XVIth International Physiological Congress in Zürich, August 14-18, 1938. The Standing Committee also had responsibility in the award of Congress Fellowships. The Federation Secretary served as ex officio on this Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The correspondence is primarily between H.S. Gasser and W.B. Cannon but includes some letter from A.C. Ivy, secretary of the American Physiological Society and D.R. Hooker, Federation Secretary and W.R. Hess of the Zürich Committee. Some correspondence covering papers submitted from: Bernard S. Oppenheimer, G. Philip Grabfield, Selig Hecht, E. Rothlin, H.K. Hartline, D.W. Bronk, Kenneth Cole, Joseph S. Fruton. Also includes handwritten note from A.V. Hill (Aug. 14, 1938) Report on Congress: Science, 88 (1938) Report to D.R. Hooker of Standing Committee by W. Cannon for meeting April 1939.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Folder 10 consists of this copy and historical notes and summaries made by Dr. Gasser. It also includes a photograph of the 7th Congress held in Heidelberg, it bears a note by HSG "Copied from photograph in possession of Johannsson, 1938" Some identification has been supplied by H.S. Gasser and further information added from Annals of Science v. 3 July 1938 pp. 241-236. "History of the International Congresses of Physiologists" by K.J. Franklin.

Correspondents include: A.V. Hill, E.D. Adrian, W.R. Hess, G. Liljestrand, Wallace Fenn, A.J. Carlson and deals with XVIIth International Congress in Oxford, Eng. 22-25 July 1947 dealing with question of not sending invitations to Germans.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: In the spring of 1941, Prof. A.V. Hill turned over the records of the Congress to H.S. Gasser for safekeeping during the bombing of London. Dr. Gasser thus became the custodian of the secretaryship. In 1946, after World War II, all records were sent to Prof. G. Liljestrand. A typescript copy of the Minute Book of the Permanent International Committee was made for Dr. Gasser's file and as a precaution against loss.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of the correspondence between H.C. Bazett, H.S. Gasser and A.C. Ivy serving as a Committee to consider the formation Of an International Union of Physiology. Consists of many suggestions and ideas from various members, penciled notes by H.S. Gasser with suggested statutes for the formation of such a union. Also included is a typescript copy of an abstract of paper "Unmedullated Fibers Originating in Dorsal Root Ganglia" submitted by H.S.G. for presentation at XVIII Congress in Copenhagen. The original statutes for the Union of Physiology were not approved, but in February of 1950 a revised version was presented for consideration of The International Council of Scientific Unions, with the proposal that the present International Committee function until the transition to Union is complete. A letter from Ralph W. Gerard of 1950 Sept. 8 reports that at the XVIIIth International Physiological Congress in Copenhagen the mission of reporting on an International Union of Physiology was accomplished and the Committee discharged.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence relating to activities as an official investigator; pledge of secrecy; correspondence dealing with interpretation of conflict of interests legislation. Correspondents include Vannevar Bush. Definition of Executive Order creating OSRD. Gasser resignation as Chairman of B-4C and appointment of Homer W. Smith. 1945. Presidential Certificate of Merit and ceremony held in New York Metropolitan area honoring recipients; photo at ceremony and copy of address by Julius Ochs Adler. Includes 17 receipts for mail of classified material and reprint: Science Vol. 110 (1941) pp. 649-651 "A Statement of NAS on AEC Fellowship Program".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Memorial minutes prepared by Jerome Greene and H.S. Gasser and J.D.R. Jr's reply to the Board (duplicated copy). Also a short biography prepared by T.J. Ross with covering letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes an exchange of letters about publicity for RI.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerns appointments to Foundation Board. Includes 1952 ed. of Charter and By-Laws; 1951 audit; summaries of 1953 Trustees' meetings. Also Foundation correspondence signed by Dean Rusk. Materials on Congressional probes of tax-exempt foundations as well as proposed I.R.S. regulations dealing with accumulation of income by charitable foundations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typescript of mss. "The relationship of RIMR to Education" with Appendix I and II which was presented in petition to U.S. Attorney General in relation to new immigration regulations 1949 October 20; also used in Annual Scientific report to Corporation v. 37 (1948). See also RG216.3. 7 items with Business Manager after retirement.
